description.narrative: Denna beredning avser ett stöd till UNDPs Strategi för Water & Oceans Governance Programme (WOGP) 2014-17. Totalt avtalsbelopp med Sida för perioden är 121 miljoner kronor och hela strategin är på 148 miljoner USD (1 milijard kronor) inklusive andra givares, främst GEFs stöd, men exclusive regeringars medfinansiering . Verksamheternas fokus ligger fortsatt på stödjandet av vattensektorreformer och stärkandet av sektorförvaltning (governance) vad gäller vattenresursförvaltning, dricksvattenförsörjning, sanitet samt hygien genom etablerade mekanismer, kanaler och program såsom WGF, GoAL-WaSH och Shared Waters Partnership. Sidas bedömning är att planerade verksamheter och aktiviteter kommer att kunna genomföras som planerat och i enlighet med uppsatta mål och förväntade resultat i UNDPs strategi. Den valda finansieringsformen är ett icke-öronmärkt programbaserat (PBA) gåvobistånd. Koordinering sker dels genom ett årligt möte samt i direkt dialog med UNDP. Uppföljning kommer, förutom genom årsgenomgångar, att ske i form av bedömning av narrativa och finansiella rapporter och annat relevant material som tas fram av programmet.

The UNDP Water Governance Program (WGP) aims towards assisting countries improve water governance, building capacities and mainstreaming effective water resources management, water supply and sanitation policy at different levels - local, national, regional and global.The support includes earlier UNDP CapNet programme.

sector.narrative: Water sector policy and administrative management

description.narrative: The WOGP works with a range of international, regional and national partners. By supporting policy advocacy, knowledge management, capacity development, and programmatic support, the WOGP assists stakeholders to reach joint agreements on priority water and ocean governance measures and reforms, and, to catalyze the necessary investments and means of implementations. Most WOGP projects are financed by vertical funds such as, the Global Environment Facility (GEF). The WOGP’s portfolio is valued at some USD351m. The support from Sida, in 2018, constituted 6,3% of the overall resources. Sida funds support activities related to knowledge management, capacity development and global policy advocacy. The work is carried forward through UNDP’s engagement in global joint discussions, as well as, regional, national and local support through the delivery mechanisms, Cap-Net (capacity development), UNDP-SIWI Water Governance Facility (global policy support and advocacy) and GoAL WASH (governance, advocacy and learning, now GoAL-WatERS). The contribution is going according to plan and, in 2018, the programme of work was in line with the objectives of the contribution and built on the priorities relating to: assessment, analysis and consensus building; commitment, planning and coordination; and making reality of reform (implementation). Based on these priorities, the WOGP worked towards the following progression of outcomes:1) Common understanding among stakeholders at different levels on gaps and barriers.2) Agreement on priority water governance reforms and/or investment priorities.3) Implementation of agreed governance frameworks and local action4) Institutional and human capacity and knowledge base strengthened to formulate and implement relevant policies, laws and strategies. Additionally, the WOGP focused on 5 thematic areas (previously 4) including: Climate-resilient access to water supply and sanitation; climate-resilient integrated water resources and coastal management; protection of transboundary surface and groundwaters in changing climate; and sustainable management of oceans in a changing climate. The new 5th thematic area grouped together the previously separate cross-cutting issues of capacity development; human rights-based approaches; water integrity; and gender. Relevant strategic developmentsIn 2018, Sida’s support to WOGP 2014 – 2018 was extended with a one-year cost extension. This was due to Sida planning the broader UNDP-Sida Framework Agreement on Environment that that is planned to encompass all UNDP interventions that are supported under the Strategy for Sweden’s global development cooperation in the areas of environmental sustainability, sustainable climate and oceans, and sustainable use of natural resources 2018–2022 (hereafter, the Strategy). Furthermore, Sida decided to phase out the funding to the thematic area “Climate-resilient access to water supply and sanitation” (WASH/ending mid-2019). This is because the strategy currently funding the WOGP does not include this priority area. Dialogue has been opened at Sida regarding possible support for this component under another strategy (SOCIAL). In the absence of funding for WASH-related activities, such engagements have started to end. A programmatic shift away from services towards freshwater and marine resources management has occurred. This means that the delivery mechanism GoAL WASH now continues under a new focus and a new (but provisional) name, GoAL-WatERS (Governance, Accountability, and Leadership/Learning in Water for Equity, Resilience and Sustainability). In 2018, the UNDP formed the Global Policy Network (GPN). The GPN incorporates the Bureau for Policy and Programme Support (BPPS) and the Crisis Response Bureau (CRB) into one global platform. The GPN thematically and technically supports the country level platforms that directly engage with country needs. The WOGP is now fitted within the Natural Capital and Environment Cluster of the GPN. The bulk of the results and impacts of WOGP is delivered by the work of the Global Environmental Finance Unit in the BPPS of the GPN. Additionally, the previously separate projects and initiatives financed through Sida support have been assembled into one larger Global Water Governance Support Programme (starting in 2019). This is to foster greater coherence and coordination across the different endeavors, networks and partnerships at local and regional levels. In this reorganization, Cap-Net activities will be implemented through the Global Water Partnership (GWP). Progress highlightsIn 2018, the WOGP was highly active in the international, regional and local fields. Internationally, it continued its global policy work and knowledge management by, for instance, contributing to important milestones such as the launch of the International Decade for Action on Water for Sustainable Development, 2018-2028, and, the UN-Water presentation of the SDG 6 Synthesis Report 2018 on Water and Sanitation at the United Nations High-level Political Forum on Sustainable Development. Additionally, WOGP contributed to important international events such as the 8th World Water Forum, the Stockholm World Water Week and the 9th GEF International Waters Conference. At the local and regional level, WOGP supported training and capacity development of institutions, along with the production and updating of toolkits and manuals for water and marine resources stewardship and management. In 2018, WOGP supported projects implemented in over 100 countries.A highlight in 2018, was the WOGP report “What works in water and ocean governance”. The report reflects on selected impact stories from the WOGP and it highlights achievements as well as critical steps and factors that made the selected set of projects reach their objectives. The report also reaffirms the importance of both management and governance and that complex and cross-sectoral water and ocean issues must be tackled jointly by all relevant actors.During 2018, expenditure on the Sida-supported work (USD3m) reached a 100% delivery against the consolidated programme Sida budget (up from 98% in 2017). According to the WOGP results matrix, many 2018 targets (24%) have been reached or surpassed and most targets that weren’t met (38%) were within the 75% reach. The contribution achieved most of its results in outcome 1 and 4, and lesser results are achieved in outcome 2 and 3 (particularly in relation to the thematic area of Climate-resilient access to water supply and sanitation). Some examples of activities implemented, and results achieved: Cap-Net - In 2018, Cap-Net successfully trained over 2000 water managers, professionals and practitioners in sustainable water management through 40+ training programmes across 102 countries. 27 affiliated networks worked together to develop capacity, 19 of which were financially supported for their management and further development. - Two Cap-Net training packages were developed during 2018: Indigenous peoples and IWRM and Climate Change Adaption and IWRM. Moreover, Cap-Net was the lead organization of the “Cross-Cutting Theme on Capacity” at the 8th World Water Forum in Brasilia. GoAL WASH (now GoAL-WatERS) - In Jordan, GoAL WASH, supported the Drought Management Unit of the Ministry of Water to improve seasonal weather forecasting and drought classification. Support was provided to set up an early warning system and to implement pilot projects putting drought management in place (water saving and water efficiency). Support has also been given to a fund for solar panels and rainwater harvesting systems, saving water and energy while reinforcing resilience at household level. - In Cambodia GoAL WASH contributed to enhancing water integrity through integrity training. The integrity Management Toolbox was used to prepare improved business models and to analyze integrity risks and identify concrete actions for implementation. Furthermore, representatives from four provinces were trained on the Governance Guidelines, including topics such as WASH Institutional functions, challenges and how to improve services at commune and village level. - In the Philippines, GoAL WASH supported the implementation of an integrated WASH approach (iWaSH). Following training supported by GoAL WASH, 16 municipalities developed iWaSH Sector Plans using the iWaSH Toolbox (training modules, assessment tools etc.). A further 345 municipalities developed sector plans supported by the Government. - In Niger, GoAL WASH supported the development of municipal water supply and sanitation plans. The government followed up on situation analyses from 12 municipalities resulting in the development of an additional 80 local water and sanitation plans covering all regions of the country. UNDP-SIWI Water Governance Facility (WGF) - During 2018, the Accountability-For-Sustainability initiative by WGF in collaboration with UNICEF produced materials such as the WASHBAT country implementation guide. A WASHBAT workshop in Iraq was conducted as a Training-of-Trainers to increase capacities of WASH stakeholders on the implementation of this tool. The WASHBAT has also been applied at municipality level (Montero, December 2018), and a training on Accountability Mapping has been conducted in 2 districts in Nigeria. - 5 videos produced with WGF support were chosen for the final selection in the “Voice of Citizens” film competition aimed at raising the voices of stakeholders on water issues from all around the world. Global Policy Work and Knowledge Management - Through a regional project, UNDP supported the holding of the East Asian Seas Congress in November 2018. The congress brought together over 1000 international and local delegates to discuss wide ranging issues, such as, marine plastic pollution. The congress resulted in senior government officials committing to, for example, developing blue economy investments, reducing or preventing marine pollution, to implement policies and programs on sustainable coastal tourism, and, to continuously align strategies with the SDGs, Aichi Biodiversity Targets and UNFCCC Paris Agreement. - Project partner GWP conducted the 2nd policymaker roundtable on water-energy-food ecosystem nexus in Skopje, FYR Macedonia in October, with over 70 participants in attendance. GWP also released the Methodological Approach for the establishment and sustaining of a Regional Dialogue and Community of Practice on Transboundary Water Management. - The WOGP supported the Fourth International Symposium on Fisheries Crime, FishCRIME 2018 by, for example, providing an extensive policy and substantive report and by financing speakers and participants, e.g. from the Marine Commodities. - Through the Atlantic and Indian Ocean SIDS IWRM project, a wide range of activities and results were achieved. For example, a National Integrated Water Resource Management (IWRM) Plan was developed, in 2018, as a strategic framework to implement National Water Policies in the countries Comoros, Mauritius and in Sao Tome & Principe, amongst other places. In Sao Tome & Principe, the IWRM Plan was followed by the National Water Act providing the legal basis to implement the plan.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
